unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Increase the Width of Confidence Interval
question_text:
Here is the formula used for constructing a confidence interval for the slope of a regression model:
$$b\pm t^{*} (SE_{b})$$

Suppose you are told that you need to increase the width of a confidence interval. All of the following answers will accomplish this except:

choices.text: Increase the value of the standard error.
Increase the value of the sample size.
Increase the value of the margin of error.

solution:
Solution

Let's look at the formula given for a confidence interval used to estimate the slope of a regression model:
$$b\pm t^{*} (SE_{b})$$

To increase the width of a confidence interval means that the margin of error must be increased. This is because the margin of error is what follows the plus or minus sign. Thus, when you are adding or subtracting a bigger number, the width will increase.

Since the margin of error is equal to the critical value times the standard error, then either of these values increasing would cause the margin of error to increase. The correct answer here is to increase the sample size. This is because the sample size, or $n$, is in the denominator of the standard error. Thus, when $n$ is increased, then the width of the confidence interval will decrease which makes this the exception.

So, Choice 'D' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because increasing the critical value increases the margin of error which increases the sample size.

Choice 'B' is incorrect because increasing the value of $t^{*}$ increases the margin of error which increases the sample size.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because increasing the standard error increases the margin of error which increases the sample size.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because increasing the margin of error increases the sample size.
